T. VAN GOOL In 1985 the first report of Enterocytozoon bieneusi in the small-intestine of an HIV-positive patient with diarrhoea was published!. After this report interest in human microsporidiosis evolved. During the first years, attention was particularly concentrated on the clinical aspects of Æ. bieneusi infection.

Diagnosis of E. bieneusi infection was performed by examination of small intestinal biopsies with electron microscopy (EM) and in a later stage also by light microscopy2. The invasive character of the biopsy procedure was most inconvenient for the patient. In addition, using electron microscopy for diagnosis was laborious and expensive. Although important clinical observations were obtained using these diagnostic procedures i.e. the association between E. bieneusi infection and the persistent diarrhoeai, studies towards human microsporidiosis remained restricted to only a limited number of medical centres.
Studies related to E. bieneusi Infection Development and use of non-invasive diagnostic techniques.

In order to find a non-invasive method to diagnose ÆE. bieneusi infection, we studied stoolspecimens for the presence of Æ. bieneusi spores using standard concentration and staining methods{. Using a Giemsa stain, spores of E. bieneusi could be identified in slides of stoolconcentrations at 1250 x magnification in light microscopy. This finding not reported before, enabled diagnosis of E. bieneusi infection to be performed with stool specimen, obviating the need for invasive techniques.

124 Although the Giemsa stain proved to be useful, some limitations were also encountered. Other faecal microorganisms were also stained and because the size of Æ. bieneusi spores and various enteric bacteria is more or less in the same range, recognition of small numbers of spores was time-consuming and difficult.
Therefore we and others initiated studies to develop diagnostic methods by which detection of the spores was more rapid and easy to perform.
We developed a new diagnostic method using the fluorescent stain Uvitex 2B which stained the chitinious inner layer of the microsporidial spore wall.

Spores of Æ. bieneusi were bright white fluorescent and could easily be recognised against a dark background. Although some other members of the faecal flora also could take up the Uvitex 2B stain (ï.e. yeast and fungal spores), spores of Æ. bieneusi could easily be discriminated because of their characteristic shape, size and the presence of a typical concave inner stripes. This latter characteristic feature of Æ. bieneusi spores was never observed in i.e. spores of fungi. The Uvitex 2B staining was fast (less than 15 min) and easy to perform Compared to results obtained with small-intestinal biopsies the Uvitex 2B technique proved to be specific and at least as sensitive.

Being a common feature of intestinal protozoa, the number of Æ bieneusi spores shedded in stool showed a considerable day-to-day variation. To improve diagnosis we therefore studied various methods to concentrate the numbers of E. bieneusi spores in faecal specimens. It was found that a water-ether sedimentation technique (WES) concentrated the number of Æ. bieneusi spores effectively in stool specimensé. With the improved sensitivity of the WES-Uvitex 2B method, spores were more easily detected in faecal specimens when sporeshedding was low. The WES-Uvitex 2B method enabled a reliable diagnosis of £. bieneusi infection by examination of one stool specimen only.

With the WES-Uvitex 2B technique screening of HIV-positive patients for intestinal Æ. bieneusi infection became a fast and easy routine procedure. The stringent criteria in which invasive diagnostic procedures were performed à, ?, were abandoned. Only two indications to start examinations for Æ. bieneusi remained, being HIV-positivity and diarrhoea. Also E. bieneusi infection in HIV-positive patients who had experienced diarrhoea in the past but were asymptomatic on the moment of stoolsampling could be assessed by this method.

Using the Uvitex 2B method we found that the prevalence of Æ. bieneusi infection was 8 % among HIV-infected patients with diarrhoea at the Academic 125 Medical Center in Amsterdamÿ, a percentage which remained constant over the last 5 years. A similar prevalence (9-16 %) was found by others using other non-invasive methods for diagnosis of E. bieneusi infection”.

Among HIV-positive patients without diarrhoea at the time stoolsamples were collected, we also observed £. bieneusi spores in stoolspecimens, indicating that infection with Æ. bieneusi was not always associated with clinical symptomatology (unpublished observations). Asymptomatic E. bieneusi infection has also been reported in other studies & ?, suggesting that other unknown factors could be involved in the pathogenesis of clinical infection due to £. bieneusi.

Afîter the introduction of the Uvitex 2B method in 1993, the usefullness of this technique has been confirmed in several other studies and is now widely used in routine clinical microbiotogy practice, 10-15, As an alternative for Uvitex 2B in some studies the fluorochrome Calcofluor white has been usedlé, 17. Although this fluorochrome is equally effective in staining the chitinious layer of the spore wall, the findings by this stain are more difficult to interpret because of a considerably stronger background immunofluorescence. Another staining technique used for recognition of Æ. bieneusi spores in stoolspecimens was introduced by Weber et all8. With this modified trichrome stain (MTS), the spores appear pinkish-red and the background stained green. Veasts and some bacteria may also take up the stain, but are differentiated from the microsporidial spores by differences in size, shape and intensity of staining. The MTS has proven to be reliable for detecting Æ. bieneusi spores in faeces and other body-fluids, and is also widely used in clinical microbiology laboratories.

With the Uvitex 2B and MTS nowadays being the techniques most often used for diagnosis of intestinal microsporidiosis, the advantages and disadvantages of both methods have been extensively debated in literaturel0, 15 17,19, Both stains are non-specific. Therefore strict adherence to precise morphologic diagnostic criteria is necessary to avoid incorrect results.

Using these morphological criteria, both techniques allow a reliable identification of spores of Æ. bieneusi. Whereas the MTS method needs only a regular light microscope, a fluorescence microscope is necessary for the Uvitex 2B technique.

However, the time required for staining and reading the smears prepared with Uvitex 2B stain (15 min) is short compared to the MTS method, which requires a preparation time of approximately 2 h, including laborious dehydration steps.

More important is that the Uvitex 2B method and also the Calcofluor white stain, 126 have proven to be more sensitive than the MTS10, 15-17, It has been recommended that the Uvitex 2B staining method should be used as a rapid, easy to perform and sensitive screening technique, and that MTS and the Giemsa staining method could, if necessary, be applied as additional methods!$. The simultaneous use of both Uvitex 2B and MTS is indeed reported with increasing frequency11-13, 15, 20, Whatever method is chosen, appropriate training of laboratory personnel in the proper handling of these methods remains the cornerstone of reliable microsporidial diagnosis. More attention should be given to this aspect than to the presumed (dis)advantages of the two methods.
Extra intestinal E. bieneusi infection.

The Uvitex 2B and MTS stain were also appropriate to examine body fluids other than stoolspecimens. Using the Uvitex 2B technique we observed E. bieneusi spores in nasal discharge and sinus aspirate specimens from an HIV-positive patient with chronic sinusitis2!. Confirmations of these light microscopic findings was obtained by EM and molecular techniques22. Using the MTS stain £. bieneusi was also observed in the broncho-alveolar lavage fluid and transbronchial lung biopsies from a patient with chronic cough and dyspnea23. In this study and in our case, E. bieneusi was also present in the small-intestine2!, 23, In AIDS patients with signs of cholangiopathy Æ. bieneusi was also found in bile samples, in ductal biliary cells and in the epithelial cells of the common bile duct and gallbladder?2 25. Although a causal relationship between microsporidial infection in the respiratory and biliary tract and the symptomatology observed in the patients was difficult to prove, the presence of E. bieneusi in the affected tissues in the absence of other known pathogens indicates a role of this parasite in the onset of such infections.
Prevalence of E. bieneusi infection in African countries.

The simplicity of the Uvitex 28 method provided the opportunity to study E. bieneusi infection in areas where diagnostic facilities were limited. Æ. bieneusi infection was known to have a cosmopolitan distribution and had been reported in patients from Europe, North- and South America and Australia26. However, from Afrika only two reports about Æ. bieneusi infection, with prevalences ranging from 1- 6,5 %, were available 27,28.

127 In Harare, Zimbabwe we studied the presence of EÆ. bieneusi infection with the Uvitex 2B method in HIV-infected persons, both adults and children, with diarrhoea??. In adults we observed a high prevalence (11 %) of E. bieneusi infection. This prevalence was similar to the prevalences reported earlier from Europe, North and South America and Australia26. E. bieneusi infection was not found in any of the HIV-positive children but £. bieneusi proved to be the most common intestinal protozoon in the adult HIV-infected population studied.
E. bienèusi infection in non-HIV infected individuals.
In the Harare study also 73 patients were examined with diarrhoea who were HIV-negative or who had no symptoms compatible with HIV-infection.

Only in one of these cases, of whom HIV serology was not available, E. bieneusi infection was observed. These findings suggested that E. bieneusi was not a major cause of diarrhoea in non-HIV infected persons, supporting earlier findings among HIV-negative patients with diarrhoea in the Netherlands. E. bieneusi was not observed in stool specimens of 282 children (0-11 years of age) with diarrhoea residing in Amsterdam, sent in by general practioners to a local medical microbiology laboratory for routine examination (unpublished results).

Since 1993, when non-invasive diagnostic techniques for Æ. bieneusi infection were introduced in routine clinical microbiology practice, until 1996, as far as we know only two HIV-negative cases with £. bieneusi infection have been reported in literature30, 31, Both cases experienced an acute self limiting diarrhoea.

One case visited Egypt and Jordan and the second Turkey. We also observed spores of £. bieneusi in a stool specimen from a non-HIV infected patient who experienced a self limiting diarrhoea for several weeks (unpublished observations) This case had not recently visited a (sub) tropical country. Also in immunocompromised, non-HIV infected patients Æ. bieneusi infection has only sporadically been reported. We did not observe E. bieneusi in stoolspecimens from 168 non-HIV infected immunocompromised patients with diarrhoea (unpublished results). Verre et al 32 in Australia also did not demonstrate E. bieneusi in 46 immunocompromised HIVnegative patients with diarrhoea.

Recently however, Æ. bieneusi was observed in a heartlung transplant recipient who was HIV-negative33. The clinical presentation and the evolution of the disease in this case were identical to those usually observed in patients with AIDS and included diarrhoea, massive weight loss and persistent infection despite treatment with albendazole. No other aetiological agent for the diarrhoea 128 was detected. His symptoms appeared following a significant and prolonged intensification of his immunosuppressive treatment. The patient had a low CD 4 Iymphocyte count (328 / LL) of unexplained origin.

From earlier studies among HIV-positive persons it was known that E. bieneusi infection was almost exclusively observed in severely immunocompromised patients with CD 4 counts of less than 50/uL26. Therefore, it seems likely that severe and prolonged cellular immunodeficiency is a prerequisite for developing clinical important persistent Æ. bieneusi infection.

Our negative results among immunocompetent individuals are in agreement with this hypothesis. By which mechanisms immunological factors provide growth of E. bieneusi in HIV-positive patients is still unknown. In experimental infection in mice, it has been shown that INFYy controls Æ. cuniculi infection by activating macrophages, vielding destruction of the infecting microsporidian33-35.
Treatment of E. bieneusi infection.

During the past 10 years much research has been directed in finding effective treatment for Æ. bieneusi infection. Use of the Uvitex 2B and MTS much facilitated the monitoring of clinical drug trials‘, 11-13, 21, Albendazole, metronidazole and paromomycine yielded symptomatic relieve in some of the patients with Æ. bieneusi infection but none of these drugs could eradicate the infection. Spores remained present in stoolspecimens and all developmental stages of the parasite continued to be present in small-intestinal biopsies26.

Anti-HIV therapy with AZT monotherapy improving the immunological status of the patients, did not influence the presence of Æ. bieneusi infection. Only most recently, with the introduction of more potent anti-retroviral combination regiments including HIV-protease inhibitors, complete cessation of shedding of E. bieneusi spores has been observed (unpublished results).

As an easy tool for fast drug screening in vitro cultivation of Æ. bieneusi has been a major research goal and much effort has bean put in developing such a system. Although short reproduction cycles of Æ. bieneusi have been observed by Visvasvara et al.36 and by our group (unpublished results), continuous culturing of Æ. bieneusi still has not been established. The reasons why E. bieneusi, in contrast to other human microsporidia like Nosema, Encephalitozoon and Pleisophora, are not cultivable in vitro remains obscur.
129 Studies related to Encephalitozoon infection Encephalitozoon (-like) infections in HIV-positive persons: early observations.

During evaluation of stoolspecimen with the Uvitex 2B method for E. bieneusi infection in HIV-positive persons with diarrhoea in 1992, we observed spores which looked different from those of Æ. bieneusi. These spores, also staining bright white with Uvitex 2B, varied considerably both in shape and size and measured 2,5-3,3 x 1,3 x 2,1 m$. Electron microscopy of intestinal biopsies of patients shedding such spores revealed that the observed parasites belonged to microsporidia of another genus: Encephalitozoon. Until than reports of Encephalitozoon infection in humans had been sparse with only two presumed HIV-negative cases being described with Encephalitozoon infection? 38. Also in HIV-positive cases Encephalitozoon infection was only occasionally reported being associated with hepatitis, peritonitis and keratoconjunctivitisi?-4l., Because Encephalitozoon cuniculi was the only Encephalitozoon species known to cause infection in animals, it was assumed that also human cases were infected with this species. However, Didier et al. observed that the Encephalitozoon-like microsporidium isolated from AÏDS-patients with keratoconjunctivitis was different from E. cuniculi and that this microsporidium should be classified as a new species: Encephalitozoon hellem“2.

Further studies with Uvitex 2B in our patients with Encephalitozoon-like infections revealed that the parasites were not only present in the intestine but that the spores were also shedded in urine samples and maxillary sinusaspirate/nasal discharge. These findings suggested that Encephalitozoon could disseminate from the presumed initial site of infection in the small intestine to other organs, a finding which had not been reported before in HIV-infected patients. Although we recognized the microsporidian as an Encephalitozoon-like species we were not able to classify the microsporidium onto species level.

In the same period Cali et al reported the finding of an Encephalitozoon-like parasite in the gastro-intestinal, urinary and respiratory tract of HIV-positive persons. On basis of EM studies this group suggested that, although there was a close resemblance with Encepha/itozoon species, certain morphological differences warranted the designation of a new genus and species: Septata intestinalis n.sp.43. Reexamination of biopsy specimens from our patients 130 showed that the Encephalitozoon-like microsporidia we observed were morphologically identical to S. intestinalis, as described by Cali et al.(unpublished results).
Encephalitozoon (-like) infections: prevalence, symptomatology and treatment.

Both the Uvitex 2B and MTS techniques proved most effective in demonstrating spores of the Encephalitozoon (-like) microsporidia £Æ. hellem,, E. cuniculi and S. in testinalls in various clinical specimens.

The availability of these techniques and awareness that Encephalitozoon-like microsporidia were associated with clinical symptomatology resulted in recent years in numerous reports of Encephalitozoon-like infections in HIV-positive patients26. The majority of patients with ÆEncephalitozoon-like infections proved to be infected with S. intestinalis and a smaller number of cases with Æ. hellem. E. cuniculi, frequent occurring in animals, was only sporadically reported in humans?6. S. intestinalis had, similar to ÆE. bieneusi, a cosmopolitan distribution but the recorded prevalence among HIV-positive persons with diarrhoea proved to be lower (2-4 %) than the prevalence reported for E. bieneusi (8-16 %). Most patients with overt Encephalitozoon-like infection were severely immunocompromized with CD 4 Iymphocyte counts ranging from 0 to 70/uL26.

Initially S. intestinalis infection was reported from HIV-positve patients with diarrhoea{4 and E. hellem from cases with keratoconjunctivitis#2. But, with more clinical cases been recognized, the site of infection and clinical symptomatology of E. hellem and S. intestinalis infection showed increasing similarities. Both £. hellem and S. intestinalis heve now been associated with chronic rhinosinusitis, tubulointerstitial nephritis and urethritis26. E. hellem has also been reported to reside in the lower respiratory tract from the tracheobronchial epithelium to the terminal bronchioles#. #6. Recently, we also observed S. intestinalis in broncho-alveolar fluid specimens from an HIV-infected patient with clinical signs of chronic severe bronchitis (unpublished observation) indicating that S. intestinalis as well as E. hellem could colonize the lower respiratory tract. Although both species appear to colonize tracheo-bronchial epithelium, clear evidence of alveolitis has not been observed.
Asymptomatic colonization of the urinary tract with both species probably is also more common than overt renal pathology.

131 To what extent the ÆEncephalitozoon-like species are associated with disease of the liver is still unknown. In HIV-positive persons, E. cuniculi was associated with hepatitisi? and in a recent study S. intestinalis was present in the liver with granulomatous inflammation and marked necrosis{7. In both cases, intracellular replication of the parasites in liver cells was observed.

Treatment was not known for Encephalitozoon-like infections. Ongoing studies with albendazole in HIV-positive patients with Æ. bieneusi infection led us and others to use this drug also in cases with S. intestinalis and E. hellem infections. In patients with signs of diarrhoea, chronic rhinosinusitis and renal failure due to infedions by these species in the intestine, nasal mucosae, and renal tissue, respectively, a rapid clinical response after albendazole treatment with complete eradication of the parasites from the infected sites was noticed26.
In vitro cultivation of Septata intestinalis.

Although in vitro cultivation of E. hellem was relatively easy#2, cultivation of S. intestinalis proved to be more fastidious and was not reported for a prolonged period of time. During our studies, aimed to culture Æ. bieneusi, we succeeded to cultivate S. intestinalis in vitro for the first time‘.

In-these studies the inoculum of the cultures consisted of microsporidian spores prepared from stoolspecimens of patients known with an heavy, EM confirmed, Æ. bieneusi infection. These spores were concentrated from stool specimens with the WES techniquef, and centrifuged on a monolayer of Rabit Kidney 13 celis in a Transwell Cultivation System. To our surprise we cultivated S. intestinalis instead of E. bieneusi, a quite remarkable finding for which an explanation was difficult to give. One of the first hypotheses was that £. bieneusi and S. intestinalis were identical, but showing each a specific morphology under different growth conditions. Such a phenomenon, known as dimorphism, is found in several other microsporidia and could well explain the results of our studies.

However, Hartskeerl ef al.4 demonstrated that Æ. bieneusi and S. intestinalis showed only 70% homology on their ssRNA genes, which excluded the hypothesis of dimorphism. Another hypothesis was that infection due to S.

intestinalis was far more common than we had expected before and that the patients we selected for (heavy) E. bieneusi infection were in fact both infected with £. bieneusi and S. intestinalis. This hypothesis was recently confirmed by 132 others who, using molecular techniques on small intestinal biopsies of patients with Æ. bieneusi infection, also obtained evidence of a dual infection of E.
bieneusi and S. intestinalis50, Reclassification of Septata intestinalis ‘0 Encephalitozoon intestinalis.

The availibilty of an unlimited number of purified spores of S. intestinalis harvested from the in vitro cultivation system enabled development of new techniques for diagnosis and to perform taxonomic studies.

Hartskeerl et al4 developed molecular techniques, including a polymerase chain reaction (PCR), for diagnosis of Encephalitozoon (-like) infections. As an additional tool to Uvitex 2B, these techniques proved most usefull for confirmation and determination of Encephalitozoon-like microsporida in various clinical specimens“l.

With respect to taxonomy, a much debated topic was whether S. intestinalis was a species of a separate genus (Sepfata) as suggested by Cali ef al.#3 or that it was a species belonging to the genus Encephalitozoon. Cali et al.

regarded the presence of certain morphological criteria of the parasite such as septation of vacuoles, tetrasporous sporogony, type 1 tubules and extravacuolar merogony as unique characters of the new genus. However, there were serious doubts about the validity of the last three characteristics as generic markers, leaving only the prominent septation of the vacuoles as the character distinguishing the genus Septata from the ÆEncephalitozoon genus*8. Using sequence analyses of the S. intestinalis rrs gene (encoding the small subunit ribosomal RNA), with rrs genes of other microsporidia, Hartskeerl et al demonstrated that rrs genes of S. intestinalis shared about 90 % sequence identity with rrs of £. cuniculi and E. hellem. This is remarkably higher than the about 70 % identity observed between rrs genes of microsporidian species which belong to different genera and suggested that S. intestinalis should be regarded as a species of the genus Encephalitozoon. Results from Western blotting studies were in agreement with these findings. Based on these results we proposed that Septata intestinalis should be reclassified as Encephalitozoon intestinalis*?.
Reclassification was not only important from the taxonomic point of view.

Regarding S. intestinalis as a species of a separate genus, not related to the Encephalitozoon species, could lead to divergence in thinking about clinical symptomatology of infections due to these species and also in different 133 approaches in treatment. However, clinical studies had already shown that E.hellem and E. intestinalis demonstrated a considerable overlap in site of infection and clinicat symptomatology and that albendazole treatment also exerted a similar efficacious effect on both species.

In addition, reclassification was important for proper use of already existing and most useful information about Encephalitozoon infections. In animals Æ. cuniculi had been recognized as an important pathogen already for a long time and much information about the pathogenesis of the infection and mechanisms of immune defenses against this species had been obtained35, 52, 53.
Assuming a close relationship between Æ. cuniculi and E. intestinalis and E.
hellem, this information is most valuable to initiate new ideas towards clinical relevance and pathogenesis of £. intestinalis and E. hellem infection in humans.
Monoclonal antibodies against Encephalitozoon intestinalis.

In contrast to Æ. bieneusi spores, the spores of Encephalitozoon species showed much variation in shape and sizeS. In addition, spores of Æ. cuniculi, E. hellem and E. intestinalis are morphologically indistinguishable. Therefore, in clinical practice there was a need for a fast and easy technique by which the nature of Encephalitozoon species involved could be determined. Use of monoclonal antibodies could be most usefull for this purpose. Production of monoclonal antibodies had become feasible because of the succesfull in vitro cultivation of £. intestinalis. Two monoclonals, one reacting with the sporewall (Si 13) and another with the extrudad filament (Si 91) of Æ. intestinalls were produced by Becker et al.54. Both monoclonals showed no cross-reactivity with E. hellem, indicating specificity on the species level. In clinical practice the monoclonals proved to be most usefull for fast confirmation and determination of Encephalitozoon spores.

Infection with Encephalitozoon in immunocompetent, non-HIV infected individuals In the past 40 years, Encephalitozoon infection in immunocompetent HIV-negative subjects was only described twice5$. Both cases were children with severe neurological symptomatology. Spores of ÆEncephalitozoon were demonstrated in cerebral spinal fluid and urine specimens?7; 38. The detection of 134 spores in these cases was difficult because sporeshedding occurred only intermittently and for a short period of time? 38. Although based on only two cases, it can be hypothesized that in immunocompetent persons in general, reproduction of Encephalitozoon (and associated sporeshedding) is only of short duration. Therefore, serological methods could be of major importance for diagnosis of such infections as well as to get insight into the prevalence of this infection among the normal population.

Earlier serological studies revealed that the antibody level against Encephalitozoon often was raised in healthy people residing in or having visited tropical countries56-5°. However, antibodies against Encephalitozoon were not or only sporadically detected in healthy persons outside tropical countriesS6, 58, 59, Because in these early serological studies only animal isolates of Æ. cuniculi could be used as antigen and the results obtained with the various serological techniques showed conflicting data, much controversy remained about the importance of serology for diagnosis of human Encephalitozoon infectionss, 60, Development of new techniques for serodiagnosis of Encephalitozoon infection.

Using in vitro cultured Æ. intestinalis for antigen preparations, we developed 3 techniques for serodiagnosis of Encephalitozoon infection, an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), a counter immuno-electrophoresis (CIE) and an immunofluorescence method (IFAT).

With these techniques serum specimens were examined from HIV-infected persons with a proven Encephalitozoon infection healthy immunocompetent persons residing in the Netherlands and France and Dutch patients with various infectious and non-infectious diseases.

As antigen in ELISA and CIE a sonicate of the culture supernatant was used. In the IFAT technique cells infected with Æ. intestinalis growing on glassslides were used as antigen. With this latter method it was possible to study in detail to which part of the parasite the antibody response was directed 1.e.

filament, sporowall and/or early developing stages both located either extracellularly or intracellularly. In serumsamples from 3 of the 8 HIV-positive patients with a proven E. intestinalis infection high antibody titers were present in the serological tests. With the IFAT it was observed that the antibody response 135 could be directed against the filament, the sporewall and/or granular material inside the vacuole. In previous serological studies with ELISA and IFAT the sporewall was used as principal antigen‘6-5°, Our studies revealed that the filament was also a major target for the antibody response in human Encephalitozoon infection. The CIE technique demonstrated positive results especially if the antibody reaction was directed against the filament as shown in the IFAT, suggesting that especially antigens of the filament are involved in the CIE reaction. The finding that only a part of the HIV-positive patients examined showed a strong antibody response against E. intestinalis is probably due to their severe immunosuppression. Also HIV-positive patients with active leishmania or toxoplasma infection often show low or even absent antibody titers in serotogic tests2?, 61, In earlier studies it was demonstrated that antigens on the sporewall of Encephalitozoon did show cross-reactivity with sporewall antigens of other microsporidia genera62. Because over 100 microsporidia genera are known and humans can be infected with at least 4 of theseG3, it is important to ascertain that the serologic response observed is related to Æ. intestinalis and not to other microsporidia. Therefore, also antigen prepared from £. hellem, E. cuniculi and Nosema comea (recently reclassified as Vittaforma comeae) as a representative of a different genus, was used in our tests. Sera from patients with a strong antibody response against Æ. intestinalis showed in all three techniques also a positive reaction with antigen of E. hellem and E. cuniculi. However, in the IFAT and CIE no reaction against N. coneum was observed, indicating that these 2 methods provide genus-specific results.

Serologic studies among healthy persons from the Netherlands and France revealed in 8 % and 5 % high antibody levels against ÆEncephalitozoon, respectively. The antibodies were predominantly directed against the filament of the parasite. This observation, not previously reported, suggests that infection with Encephalitozoon is a common occurring event in the non-HIV infected Dutch and French population.

Because immunocompetent cases with a parasitological proven E. intestinalis infection are unknown, the serologic reaction during or after an acute Encephalitozoon infection has not been studied . So it is unknown to which part of the parasite the initial serologic response is directed, whether different isotypes are involved and whether elevated antibody titers remain. Also precise 136 cut off levels of the tests need to be determined. In our study cut off levels were arbitrarely choosen (on a high level) which could in fact have resulted in an underestimation of the true prevalence of the infection.
Future challenges.

Because clinical data were not available of the immunocompetent populations studied, it is still unknown whether the presence of antibodies against Encephalitozoon is associated with symptomatic disease Several features of Encephalitozoon infection i.e. the disseminating character of the infection, the preference of the parasites for certain (i.e renal and neural) tissues and the severe symptomatology observed in the immunocompromised host, show much similarity with Toxoplasma gondii infection. In analogy with toxoplasmosis, it is possible that in immunocompetent persons acute Encephalitozoon infection will in most cases be asymptomatic and only occasionaly lead to symptomatic disease. That in immunocompetent individuals Encephalitozoon infection can cause severe pathology, was illustrated by the two cases reported with Encephalitozoon infection?7. 38.

In future studies it could be of value to study in more detail clinical syndromes having up to now no distinct pathogenesis, i.e. some forms of encephalitis, interstitial nephritis and granulomatous liver disease for an associaton with ÆEncephalitozoon infection. In animals, including squirrel monkeys and baboons, Encephalitozoon infection is known as an important cause of severe congenital infection. Whether congenital transmission in humans is also possible is unknown but deserves further study.

To study the clinical importance of ÆEncephalitozoon infection in immunocompetent humans the use of both morphological, serologic and molecular diagnostic techniques is of major importance. Together with a careful clinical observation and follow up, the use of these new techniques should enable us to get insight whether Encephalitozoon infection is of clinical importance in the immunocompetent human host.

145 Bulletin de la Société Française de Parasitologie 1998, Tome 16, n° 1 LES PROTOZOOSES ÉMERGENTES LA PARASITOLOGIE DE DEMAIN J. DUPOUY-CAMET ET J.-J. ROUSSET C'est une épidémie de pneumocystose, à l'époque considérée comme une protozoose, qui a révélé l'épidémie de Sida au début des années 80 aux Etats-Unis. L'épidémie de SIDA ainsi que la multiplication des causes d'immunodépression (greffes d'organes, chimiothérapies..) ont provoqué une évolution considérable de la protozoologie médicale. Des formes cliniques particulières de protozooses déjà connues ont été observées avec une plus grande fréquence: toxoplasmoses cérébrales ou disséminées, leishmanioses viscérales de traitement difficile. Des parasitoses, connues dans d'autres espèces animales mais méconnues ou rarissimes chez l'homme, se sont révélées chez l'immunodéprirné comme des maladies graves: cryptosporidioses et microsporidioses intestinales ou disséminées..

L'utilisation de colorations spéciales des selles a contribué à la découverte d'un protozoaire inconnu, Cyclospora cayetanensis, responsable de diarrhées chez le voyageur tropical. Les articles de E. Pozio et de Tom Van Gool dans le présent numéro décrivent avec précision ces nouveaux parasites.

L'émergence de ces nouvelles protozooses s'est accompagnée d'améliorations des techniques diagnostiques (cultures cellulaires, PCR...), de la recherche de nouvelles molécules, de l'utilisation de nouveaux protocoles thérapeutiques ou prophylactiques (atovaquone, ampholiposomes, albendazole..).

Le traitement classique de ces protozooses est assez décevant et ne semble efficace que si le patient a une immunité correcte. F. Derouin fait le point sur ces nouvelles molécules utilisables et, surtout, sur de nouvelles formulations qui en accroissent l'activité. L'utilisation récente de là trithérapie a fait chuter l'incidence de ces protozooses chez les Sidéens mais ces protozoaires demeurent toujours présents chez les patients atteints d'autres immunodépressions et leur meilleure connaissance permet un diagnostic et une prise en charge rapide.

Les dernières années ont vu également progresser les connaissances pour d'autres protozooses: il existe en France un programe de prévention efficace de la 146 toxoplasmose congénitale, l'espoir déçu d'un vaccin antipaludéen a néanmoins facilité l'affinage d'une méthodologie d'essai vaccinal à grande échelle sur le terrain, l'analyse moléculaire a différencié au sein de l'espèce Entamoeba histolytica des isolats non pathogènes et a identifié des molécules impliquées dans la virulence, à la base de prototypes vaccinaux. P Garavelli discute ci-dessus de la pathogénicité possible d'un protozoaire de classification encore incertaine et très souvent retrouvé à l'examen parasitologique des selles: Blastocystis hominis..

Si les progrès de la thérapeutique ont amélioré la prise en charge de beaucoup de ces protozooses, il n'en demeure pas moins vrai que certaines risquent de poser de gros problèmes au cours du prochain siècle. Il est paradoxal de constater que la lutte antibactérienne s'enrichit chaque année de nouveaux antibiotiques alors que l'on attend encore des amæbicides de contact non toxiques et que l'on peut mourir de leishmaniose autour de la Méditerranée: la trypanosomose africaine explose dans certaines régions en raison de troubles socio-politiques majeurs et il n'existe pas, en pratique, d'autre alternative thérapeutique qu'un dérivé arsenical, mal toléré et mis au point depuis un demi- siècle; le réchauffement attendu de la planète risque d'accroître l'extension géographique d'un paludisme souvent chimiorésistant et déjà responsable d'un million de morts par an. La protozoologie médicale a, hélas, un grand avenir.

147 Bulletin de la Société Française de Parasitologie 1998, Tome 16, n° 1 ANALYSE D'OUVRAGE DES COMPAGNONS DE TOUJOURS IV. LA MOUCHE Auteur : J.-M. DOBY Professeur émérite de Parasitologie (Rennes) Le dernier des fascicules que le Professeur Doby a consacrés à nos compagnons de toujours a pour sujet la mouche. Certes, comme le souligne l'auteur, la mouche n'est pas un parasite au sens zoologique du terme mais, étymologiquement, elle peut être considérée comme telle puisqu'elle partage notre nourriture (para et sitein, se nourrir en grec) et comme un compagnon (cum et panis, le pain en latin).

Selon son habitude l'auteur nous présente d'abord l'insecte en entomologiste et en historien de l'entomologie scientifique. Puis nous apprenons tout sur le rôle de la mouche dans la vie de l'homme, de l'antiquité à nos jours, sur les moyens de lutte proposés, moyens magiques et scientifiques, et sur son action éventuellement bénéfique.

Dans les deux-tiers restants du livre, nous avons l'impression de lire des résumés de plusieurs thèses; en effet, magistralement, avec une démonstration de ce que peut être la culture des universitaires, le Professeur Doby se montre linguiste, onomatologiste ou botaniste. L'héraldique, la mode, la poésie, la prose, le théatre, la chanson sont successivement étudiés mais c'est dans le chapitre des arts figuratifs que l'auteur montre encore plus l'étendue de ses connaissances et de son travail de recherche. Ses études sur les "Vanités" à elles seules représentent un document que des enseignants d'histoire de l'art m'ont demandé; que dire des dessins réunis par ailleurs? Toujours beaucoup de travail.
La sculpture, la bande dessinée, la carte postale et même la philatélie sont survolées.

La perfection n'est pas humaine et l'aide d'un cinéphile aurait permis d'éviter une petite erreur sur le "Mouton à cinq pattes" ou d'évoquer ce jeune portoricain capturant une mouche à l'aide des baguettes de son maître japonais et 149 sans doute d'autres films dont les noms sont sortis de notre mémoire mais nous non plus ne sommes pas spécialiste du septième art.
Une bibliographie de 287 noms ouvre les possibilités, à ceux qui le désirent, d'approfondir un peu plus chacun des points abordés dans les 260 pages de ce petit livre.
Ajoutons que l'on trouve, dans cet ouvrage, une iconographie remarquable tant en noir et blanc qu'en couleurs (douze pages).

Nous sommes sûr que tous ceux qui ont acheté les trois premiers livres se hâteront de commander le dernier et le seul espoir que nous ayons c'est qu'un éditeur de renommée internationale reprenne l'ensemble pour une large diffusion bien méritée à notre avis.
